questions.title: Complex Impedance Calculation
questions.question_text: Calculate the complex impedance Z for a circuit with R = 50Ω in series with a capacitor C = 10μF at frequency f = 1000 Hz. Use the formula: $$Z = R + j\omega C$$ where $$\omega = 2\pi f$$ and $$j = \sqrt{-1}$$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Remember: For a capacitor, $$X_C = \frac{1}{\omega C}$$ and the impedance is $$Z = R - jX_C$$

questions.title: Fourier Series Coefficient
questions.question_text: Find the first harmonic coefficient $$a_1$$ for the Fourier series of the periodic function $$f(t) = t$$ for $$-\pi < t < \pi$$ with period $$T = 2\pi$$. Use: $$a_n = \frac{2}{T}\int_{-T/2}^{T/2} f(t)\cos(n\omega_0 t)\,dt$$ where $$\omega_0 = \frac{2\pi}{T}$$. Enter your answer to 3 decimal places.
questions.feedback_correct: Excellent! Since $$f(t) = t$$ is an odd function and $$\cos(n\omega_0 t)$$ is even, their product is odd. The integral of an odd function over a symmetric interval is zero, so $$a_1 = 0$$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Consider the symmetry: $$f(t) = t$$ is odd, $$\cos(\omega_0 t)$$ is even. What happens when you integrate an odd function over $$[-\pi, \pi]$$?

questions.title: Transfer Function Analysis
questions.question_text: Given the transfer function $$H(s) = \frac{10s}{s^2 + 3s + 2}$$, what are the poles and zeros of this system?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Zeros occur when the numerator equals zero: $$10s = 0 \Rightarrow s = 0$$. Poles occur when the denominator equals zero: $$s^2 + 3s + 2 = (s+1)(s+2) = 0 \Rightarrow s = -1, -2$$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Find zeros by setting the numerator to zero, and poles by setting the denominator to zero. Factor $$s^2 + 3s + 2$$.

questions.title: Laplace Transform Property
questions.question_text: The Laplace transform of the derivative satisfies: $$\mathcal{L}\{f'(t)\} = s\mathcal{L}\{f(t)\} - f(0)$$ where $$f(0)$$ is the initial condition at $$t = 0$$.
questions.feedback_correct: True! This is the fundamental differentiation property of Laplace transforms: $$\mathcal{L}\{\frac{df}{dt}\} = s F(s) - f(0^-)$$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Review the differentiation property of Laplace transforms. The initial condition $$f(0)$$ appears as a constant term.

questions.title: RMS Voltage Calculation
questions.question_text: Calculate the RMS (Root Mean Square) value of the voltage $$v(t) = 10\sin(\omega t) + 5\cos(2\omega t + \frac{\pi}{4})$$ volts. Use the formula: $$V_{RMS} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{T}\int_0^T v^2(t)\,dt}$$. Enter your answer in volts to 2 decimal places.
questions.feedback_incorrect: For a sum of sinusoids, $$V_{RMS}^2 = \sum_{i} \frac{V_i^2}{2}$$ where $$V_i$$ are the peak amplitudes.

questions.title: Matrix Eigenvalue Problem
questions.question_text: Find the eigenvalues of the matrix $$\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$$. Use the characteristic equation $$\det(\mathbf{A} - \lambda\mathbf{I}) = 0$$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For an upper triangular matrix, the eigenvalues are the diagonal elements: $$\lambda_1 = 3, \lambda_2 = 2$$
questions.feedback_incorrect: For triangular matrices, the eigenvalues are simply the diagonal elements. Check $$\det\begin{pmatrix} 3-\lambda & 1 \\ 0 & 2-\lambda \end{pmatrix} = (3-\lambda)(2-\lambda) = 0$$
